Award.AwardTitle: Planning a Dual Institution Research Center in Socially Relevant Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Morehouse and Spelman Colleges will plan and design a collaborative center in Socially Relevant Computing. The center will provide interdisciplinary education, research, and workforce development for African American undergraduate computer science students, particularly those who are at risk for degree completion. In addition, the center will create an ecosystem of partners to conduct research that leads to innovations to address critical societal problems of national priority and demonstrated interventions to increase the representation of African Americans in graduate school and the STEM workforce.

The principal investigators will implement the proposed project in multiple stages that include an internal assessment of capability and infrastructure requirements, an external assessment of relevant existing computer science centers for benchmarking, curriculum enhancements, and a pilot education research project to test an evidence-based socially relevant computing intervention concept. The project will help articulate strategies for developing degree pathways to increase persistence in computing for African Americans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award entitled “Planning a Dual Institution Research Center in Socially Relevant Computing” was a major success in developing the research infrastructure in socially relevant computing at two historically Black colleges, Morehouse College and Spelman College. There were two main outcomes on the Morehouse College portion of the award. First, there was a new degree program that is under review that focuses on Human-Centered Computing. Students in this new major would take core computer science courses in addition to multiple relevant Psychology courses (including three research method courses) that will enable these students to do more research as it pertains to socially relevant computing. The second major outcome is the appointment of the principal investigator Dr. Kinnis Gosha with an Adjunct Assistant Professor position at Georgia Tech. This position will allow Dr. Gosha to be able to advise students enrolled in the Master’s program in Human Computer Interaction in their Department of Interactive Computing. These students will either come from his lab or from other historically Black colleges. Dr. Gosha is currently a Masters thesis advisor for an African American female who graduated with a Bachelors in Computer Science from historically Black university, Hampton University. Additionally, several undergraduate students at Morehouse and Spelman participated in socially relevant computing research projects that lead to a multiple research publications being published in respected peer reviewed venues, undergraduate African American students accepted in top graduate programs in computer science and one prestigious graduate fellowship award from the National Science Foundation.
